title: Wednesday, 6th February 2019

Let me grab some sellside here. Peel Hunt -- who'd gone all in on the idea that Ocado's a tech stock, to remind -- have folded already.

BE11:22am

The company announced yesterday lunchtime a fire at its
Andover CFC. This was the first warehouse that uses robotics,
the technology that it is licencing to its new clients around the
world. Given the damage has been worse than first reported,
including that “during the night part of the roof collapsed and
there has been substantial damage to the majority of the building
and its contents”, this is likely to have a substantial impact on its
Ocado.com customer experience and, whilst it is covered by
insurance, could do lasting damage over at least the next 12
months, including a “reduction in sales growth until we can
increase capacity elsewhere.” For the time being, we downgrade
to a Hold, target price 1,000p, until we get a better idea of the
outcome. However, our core thesis licencing the technology to
food retailers around the world, has not changed.

nightingale20201 Peel Hunt had a price target of further 70% upside before the fire
Tom Dalgleish Fire sprinklers in an automated warehouse could destroy the whole joint anyway

11:26 am
BE11:26am

There are a few ways to look at this news:

1. It is a material dent in the UK retail business (i.e. 10%, probably less as other warehouses are scaled up)

2. For those investors who mainly value Ocado as a technology business, this 10% dent in the near term, should not make a huge difference.

3. What is totally unclear to us at this stage is whether the cause of the fire (unknown right now) has any implications for the technology platform itself.

Yesterday, the CEO mentioned a new generation of robots which will be able to identify leaks and should reduce the need for specialist engineers on site, effectively pre-empting a problem within the grid and resolving the issue. It would be interesting to know whether this technology would have avoided this fire, but as long as there are no details about the cause of the fire, this is a moot point.

The 8% share price drop, for a near term 10% cut in capacity in the least valuable part of the business (i.e. retail), seems a big over reaction and therefore provides another opportune entry point for the Ocado tech investment case, in our view.

qwerty Victrex consensus of £125m unchanged despite Q1. Jan very strong.
BE11:27am

....course, it's also a post-results day so we have cautious comment on Ocado even ignoring that it's on fire.

CS1 @FATDAZ: and their disaster recovery policy!
nightingale20201 retail makes up 90% of the overall revenue
BE11:28am

Andrew Gwynn of Exane is, as ever, very good on the theme.

11:28 am
BE11:28am

The prospect of Ocado delivering EBIT short-term was remote and has become even more so. Many readers will question whether that matters; the group has just signed up some of the biggest retailers in the world to its ‘smart platform’. Further, the application of IFRS-15 (revenue) means that revenue from those contracts is deferred even if the start-up costs aren’t. So perversely, the worse profit is, the better it is for the equity story. The cash flow is another story however and with more cash burn than we expected going forward, we take our TP to 700p (from 800p).

FATDAZ @Lemmy thanks for heads up
FATDAZ @CS1 yes indeed
BE11:29am

He notes £115m of deferred payments on the balance sheet, versus a capex guide of £350m.

BE11:29am

"we think the group will need about £700m more liquidity to get their contracts up and running."

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Which loops us back to Exane's core argument with Ocado ......

BE11:30am

We’re not convinced that Kroger can find demand to fill 20 CFCs across the next 5 years given the still glacial pace of online grocery growth in the US. We could be wrong but time and time again we come back to key point; the problem with Ocado isn’t the tech but rather, its application to low margin food. If Ocado’s retail partners are losing money selling food online, can Ocado make a lot of money?

nightingale20201 give or take, Byrce....the extra liquidity cited would be around £1 per share
BE11:30am

A question we've been asking for what feels like 20 years.

Victrex PLC (VCT:LSE): Last: 2,366, up 19.6 (+0.84%), High: 2,376, Low: 2,164, Volume: 309.84k

BE11:33am

And Q1's mixed. Year's started pretty bad in terms of volume but management's comfortable with year-end forecasts.

Soundbuy *East
11:33 am
BE11:34am

At least in terms of PBT, because lower volume means lower bonuses.

BE11:34am

Have Barclays to summarise.

BE11:35am

First quarter volumes of 822t were down -22% on last year. Loss of the iPhone order pushed that down c.11% and we estimate lower demand and de-stocking in autos contributed another -6% to the decline which implies the rest of the business contributed c.5-6% to lower volumes. Some of that is was likely from non-iPhone consumer electronics and we believe the company sold trial volumes this time last year for a new project which probably didn’t recur. Revenue was -19% at £64.1mn but, importantly, ASP was +4% from £74.9/kg last year to £78.0/kg even with currencies turning negative. Having spoken to the company it sounds like this was a combination of lower VAR volume, which includes some of the auto demand and generally comes at a lower price point, and positive local currency revenue growth in Medical. The company advised against extrapolating that ASP gain over the next three quarters and believes a flat or slightly higher ASP in FY19 is more likely; consensus has a slight decline so that’s an upside surprise. There’s no official Q1 consensus but we believe most were expecting something around 850t so this is slightly below.

11:34 am
BE11:35am

That said, Victrex’s 2019 P/E of 18.6x is at the top end of its historic trading range which we think investors will increasingly question with both volume and revenue falling double-digits and that’s the crux of our UW thesis.

FJ Electric milk floats are the future...
Lemmy Soundbuy: maybe Ocado can launch a new "smoked" range?
BE11:36am

And Numis.

BE11:36am

Against tough comparatives the weak start to the 2019 fiscal year indicated by today's AGM and Q1 Interim Management Statement includes volumes and sales declines of 22% and 18%, respectively, in the first quarter of the year, as weakness in the Automotive and Value Added Reseller sectors contributed to a 13% decline in core volumes in Q1 2019. Management's outlook for H2 2019 is unchanged, and despite some initial improvement in January and February, H1 2019 is expected to be much weaker than the prior year. On today's call with management we will look for further clarity on the recent improvement cited, but initially see scope for a further 1-2% reduction to estimates.

11:36 am
BE11:37am

Morgan Stanley also cautious, saying hitting FY PBT will be a stretch.

BE11:37am

If we account for an FX and energy headwind of £6-8m, the fall-away of the consumer electronics volumes of ~£3-5m, an additional investment in SG&A of ~£5m (previously guided to £8-9m), and a tailwind of £14m from the absent bonus accrual; then to achieve cons. PBT implies the underlying business will need to grow mid to high single digit in the second half and associated operating leverage. Bottom line… given lack of visibility in valueadded resellers, weaker autos and electronics, and the recent weakness in the energy markets, we continue to see more downside risk to cyclical volumes than is implied. We're Underweight.

BE11:41am

It divides between £169m of cash-pay interest and £181m of non-cash pay debt, which give leverage of less than 1x on the cash pay and c. 2x in total, which compares to the company’s target of 1.5x by year end. We do not know the cost of the debt. However, the statement notes that bonding remains available and there is an additional £75m facility with a 2022 maturity. In other news, Coltrane has requisitioned a meeting to change all of the management , apart from Debbie White, the CEO. Our view: There is no comment on current trading, but we believe that there are cost overruns on the Energy from Waste plants. We believe that this is an intelligent deal which seeks to secure the future of the business, whilst providing some return to the banks. Listing rules require a 25% free float, so the future as a listed business will depend on the number of institutions who subscribe at strike, or future placings. If the deal is blocked, like Mouchel was, we believe that there may be no value at all in the existing equity.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

And the strength of the rally mostly reflects the underperformance post Metro's warning last month. The statement's fine rather than opinion changing.

BE11:49am

Citi incoming:

BE11:49am

Net positive statement, with medium term potential acquisition
synergies increased (+4% to consensus FY22 PBT) and FY19 NIM outlook
increased. 1Q19 NIM is better (172bps vs 166bps consensus for 1H19), which helped drive a slightly better underlying cost-income (less than 60% vs 60% consensus), but offset by higher cost of risk. CET1 ratio is broadly in-line. Given the more resilient NIM in 1Q, CYBG has upgraded FY19 NIM outlook to 165-170bps, at the upper end of previous 160-170bps range. This is also after having completed the review of EIR accounting, but does assume broadly stable pricing, which sounds optimistic in our view, given continued strong mortgage pricing pressure. Consensus FY19 NIM is 166bps.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Volume growth is solid, helped by strong starting liquidity and is better vs consensus. 1Q19 loans are £71.9bn vs 1H19E consensus £71.5bn with better SME (“at attractive margins”) and mortgages but lower unsecured. Stronger volumes drove 1Q19 NIM of 172bps vs 1H19E consensus NIM of 166bps. Having reviewed EIR accounting CYBG now guides to FY19 NIM of 165-170bps, at the upper end of the previous 160-170bps target range. However this assumes broadly stable pricing, which sounds optimistic given the sustained pricing pressure in mortgages.

BE11:50am

CYBG now expects to realise £150m of run-rate synergies in FY21, above the previously guided £120m. The additional £30m is 4% of consensus FY22 PBT. CYBG has reconfirmed less than £950m costs for FY19; this is in-line with consensus £941m and is confident of delivering year 1 synergies as planned (c£36m). Given the better-than-expected revenue generation, the 1Q19 u/lying cost-income of

Pharma @1st, I will muse on that when I go round the supermarket tonight to stock up on food.
DJ @pharma aye aye comrade
BE11:51am

.... less than 60% vs 60% consensus. For one-off costs, CYBG noted that PPI charges in 1Q19 came in-line with expectations while it also took £161m of exceptional charges.

11:51 am
BE11:51am

Capital's fine at 14.5%. Charges are as expected.

BE11:52am

These are good results. The additional synergies are clearly
positive while the higher NIM guidance is too, albeit stable pricing assumption seems optimistic in our view. However given the negative expectations, we expect a positive investor reaction to these results. We have a Buy rating, target 230p.

1st Lt. Fletcher Christian @pharma - I don't need confirmation from the Tory die hards. The evidence is all there to see. Carillion, Thames Water etc.. etc..

11:52 am
BE11:52am

While we have previously regarded CYBG as having similar challenges as the larger UK banks with low returns, bloated cost base, legacy conduct costs, the expected cost synergies from the merger will significantly improve profitability despite our concerns regarding margin pressure at Virgin Money. Moreover, the combined group will be significantly overcapitalised following the improvement in Virgin Money’s CET1 ratio following PRA approvals for mortgage RWA models in July 2018 and accreditation of IRB models for CYBG from FY2019. We estimate CYBG’s pro-forma FY2021E RoTE will improve to 11.6%, driven by our assumption that £100m of the £120m cost synergies identified by management will be recognised in that year.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

At its 1H results, Barratt reported forward sales up 7% year-on-year, and reported revenues grew 7.2% to £2.132bn, well above the consensus for FY, which forecasts growth of +1%. The group also delivered a 200bps increase in gross margins to 23% and a 130bps increase in operating margins to 19%, meaning 1H basic EPS grew 21% to 32.7p (FY Jun18: 66.5p), well above 1H consensus of 29.5p. The group's net private reservations rate per active outlet was 0.74 (FYJun18: 0.78). Net cash was £388m (FYJun18: £791m, Dec 17: £166m).

CS1 UK100 going south.
Viking1 Should read ...Another ...
BE12:00pm

(@marktime: thanks, but I have to be in London.)

BE12:01pm

Barratt remains the cheapest of the pan-UK volume housebuilders we cover, trading on a 1.5x TBV, with more room than peers to improve margins and returns, in our view – hence our Overweight. We note that Barratt, and the overall UK housebuilding sector, now trades on less than 9x trailing P/E, despite the strong bounce in share prices in January; and that with near-record levels of cash on the balance sheet. House price growth momentum has been slowing (Exhibit 2), but historically these P/E levels would imply EPS decline 1 year forward, which contrasts strongly with the double digit growth delivered by Barratt today

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

The group announced an ongoing commitment to ordinary dividend cover at 2.5 times (not new), but also clarified its intention to pay special dividends of £175m in November 2019 (not new) and £175m in November 2020 (new).

12:02 pm
BE12:03pm

Redrow has seen 12% volume growth in H1 and appears to be on
course for another good year of growth for the full year 2018/19.
The additional dividend payment takes the company more in line
with its larger peers in terms of yield and should provide good
valuation support in the short term.

BE12:03pm

Redrow this morning released interim results to end-December 2018. The
company completed 2,970 units in the first half of the financial year, up 12% compared to H1 2017/18. Private average selling price (ASP) was 4% higher at £391,000. The group delivered an operating margin of 19.3%, marginally below the 19.7% delivered in H1 last year. Sales rates for the half were 0.61, somewhat below the 0.64 seen in the same period of the previous year.
Redrow closed the year with a net cash position of £101m, up from the June 2018 level of £63m. In light of the growing cash pile, the group has (in addition to a 10p interim dividend) proposed a 30p additional cash return. This should take the full year dividend to c.60p, and thus a dividend yield of c.10% is now available in the current year.

12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

Canaccord.

BE12:05pm

Interim results are in line at the PBT level, with revenue higher and margins a bit lower than we expected. Comments on recent trading are reassuring but it is still early days. Private sales seem to have bounced back in recent weeks. Balance sheet remains in decent shape as expected. The big surprise is a 30p one off cash return to shareholders in addition to an interim dividend of 10p. There is no change to guidance and we would not expect any material change to consensus. The cash return should be well received particularly given that it is coming from a housebuilder focused on growth and delivering very good NAV per share growth. Shares now offer good growth with a very attractive yield for this year (note: 30p likely to be treated as a capital gain by UK tax residents). We reiterate our BUY rating.

Expect Adjusted EPS to decline -5% to -9% CER reflecting recent approval of a generic competitor to Advair in the US.
Guidance also reflects expected impact of Tesaro acquisition and assumes Consumer Healthcare nutrition disposal
and Consumer JV with Pfizer close as previously indicated
• Expect 80p dividend for 2019

BE12:11pm

In 2019, we now expect Adjusted EPS to decline in the range of -5% to -9% at CER. This guidance reflects
the recent approval of a substitutable generic competitor to Advair in the US and the expected impact of the
Tesaro acquisition and assumes that the proposed Consumer Healthcare nutrition disposal closes by the end
of 2019 and the proposed Consumer Healthcare Joint Venture with Pfizer closes during H2 2019.
GSK expects to maintain the dividend for 2019 at the current level of 80p per share.
All expectations, guidance and targets regarding future performance and dividend payments should be read
together with “Outlook, assumptions and cautionary statements” on page 45.
If exchange rates were to hold at the closing rates on 31 January 2019 ($1.31/£1, €1.14/£1 and Yen 143/£1)
for the rest of 2019, the estimated positive impact on 2019 Sterling turnover growth would be less than 1%
and if exchange gains or losses were recognised at the same level as in 2018, the estimated positive impact
on 2019 Sterling Adjusted EPS growth would be around 1%.
